body_text.text: Methods: We report on our experience in the management of patients with AML older than 70 years, who were treated at our department between 11/03 and 12/06. 17 patients older than 70 years (median age 76 years, ranges 70-94) were diagnosed as AML by bone marrow puncture.
body_text.section: Chemotherapy in patients older than 70 years with acute myeloid leukemia -a single institution experience

body_text.text: Results: Because of comorbidity and poor performance status 7 patients were treated by supportive care only. In 10 patients AML-chemotherapy was administered. Induction chemotherapy consisted of daunorubicin 45 mg/m 2 /d d1-3, etoposide 100 mg/m 2 /d d1-5, and ARA-C 2 × 100 mg/m 2 /d d1-7. In 1 patient with secondary AML idarubicin 10 mg/m 2 /d d1-3 was administered instead of daunorubicin. In case of non achievement of CR after the first chemotherapy cycle a second induction therapy was given (2+5+5, MIDAC). For patients achieving remission intermediate dose ARA-C 2 × 1 g/m 2 /d d1,3,5 was given as consolidation treatment. 6 of 10 patients (60%) who were treated with intensive chemotherapy achieved CR. 2 patient died during the first 6 weeks following initiation of chemotherapy. The median duration of remission was 11 months. The 2 year survival of these patients is 44%. Patients treated with supportive care alone had a median survival of 1 month.
body_text.section: Chemotherapy in patients older than 70 years with acute myeloid leukemia -a single institution experience

body_text.text: Conclusions: Our results indicate that intensive chemotherapy is feasible in patients older than 70 years. The toxicity profile is acceptable in these patients and the remission rate is in the range reported in studies which included adult patients with lower age. For some patients older than 70 years chemotherapy offers the chance to achieve complete remission and to regain their living conditions they had before development of AML. Background: The intrinsic antiangiogenic protein vasohibin has been shown to be a negativ feedback-regulator of VEGF and bFGF signalling in human endothelial cells. It has been reported recently, that VASH1 acts specifically on endo-thelial cells. Therefore, VASH1 has been considered as a canditate for antiangiogenic therapies, but intracellular processing and secretion of VASH1 are still unknown, due to the lack of a classical signal peptide sequence in the protein. Moreover, a novel alternative splicing isoform (VASH1B) was studied for its antiangiogenic effects in comparison to the main VASH1 product (VASH1A).
body_text.section: Chemotherapy in patients older than 70 years with acute myeloid leukemia -a single institution experience

body_text.text: Methods: The regulation of VASH1 gene expression by angiogenic cytokines (TGF-β1, bFGF and VEGF) was analyzed by RT-qPCR and Western blots. Subcellular localization studies were performed by transfection of FLAG-tagged proteins in primary endothelial cells and immunofluorecence analysis with wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) for glycoproteins of the Golgi apparatus, von Willebrand Factor (vWF) for secretory organelles and with DAPI for cell nuclei. Moreover, cell proliferation, migration and capillary formation was studied 5 days after adenoviral transfection of GFP, VASH1A and VASH1B. Cell numbers were determined by a Bürker-Chamber, cell migration in scratch assays and capillariy formation in Matrigel ® -assays.
body_text.section: Chemotherapy in patients older than 70 years with acute myeloid leukemia -a single institution experience

body_text.text: Results: VASH1A and 1B were upregulated only by VEGF stimulation. Both isoforms localized to cytoplasm and nucleus, due to a N-terminal nuclear localization sequence. In contrast mVASH, lacking the NLS domain, was localized in vesicles in the cytoplasm and did not show any colocalization with Golgi Apparatus and endoplasmatic reticulum. No VASH1 protein or proteolytical fragments were detected in the respective culture supernatants. Adenoviral overexpression of the alternative splicing isoform VASH1B in endothelial cells resulted in a significant inhibition of cell growth, migration and capillary formation. This was not observed with the major isoform VASH1A.
body_text.section: Chemotherapy in patients older than 70 years with acute myeloid leukemia -a single institution experience

body_text.text: Conclusions: In contrast to previous reports we were not able to demonstrate efficient secretion of the VEGF target protein VASH1 by primary endothelial cells. Both isoforms of human VASH1 localized to the cytoplasm and nucleus, whereas murine VASH1, lacking the NLS domain, localized only to cytoplasmatic vesicles. Moreover, antiangiogenic effects were only observed with the alternative splicing variant VASH 1B and not with the major form VASH1A. Based on these observations endothelial cell specificity and intracellular interaction partners mediating the antiangiogenic effects of VASH1B still remain to be investigated.
body_text.section: Chemotherapy in patients older than 70 years with acute myeloid leukemia -a single institution experience

body_text.text: M. Kneidinger 1 , K. Gleixner 1 , A. Böhm 1 , M. Weghofer 2 , C. Lupinek 2 , S. Vrtala 2 , R. Valenta 2 , G. Superti-Furga 3 , F. Y. Lee 4 , P. Valent 1 Background: Dasatinib (BMS354825) is a small molecule-type inhibitory drug that blocks several tyrosine kinases including PDGFR, KIT, BCR/ABL, and several src kinases. Dasatinib has recently been introduced as a new effective antileukemic drug in patients with imatinib-resistant chronic myeloid leukemia. However, because of the many targets of dasatinib and the broad range of potential target-cells in physiologic and pathologic tissues, dasatinib has recently been examined for its immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory effects.
body_text.section: Inhibition of IgE-dependent activation and histamine release in human basophils by Dasatinib

body_text.text: Methods and results: We here report that dasatinib at 1 µM completely blocks the anti-IgE-induced release of histamine in human blood basophils in healthy subjects. The effects of dasatinib on histamine secretion in basophils were dosedependent (IC 50 : 50-100 nM). Dasatinib was also found to block recombinant allergen-induced release of histamine from human basophils in sensitized individuals. In addition, as assessed by flow cytometry, dasatinib (1 µM) was found to inhibit the IgE-dependent upregulation of several activationlinked antigens, including aminopeptidase N (CD13), LAMP-3 (CD63), endolyn (CD164), and the basophil-specific ectoenzyme E-NPP3 (CD203c) on the cell surface of human basophils. The effects of dasatinib on upregulation of basophil differentiation antigens were found to be dose-dependent and were seen in normal subjects as well as in allergic individuals.
body_text.section: Inhibition of IgE-dependent activation and histamine release in human basophils by Dasatinib

body_text.text: Conclusions: Dasatinib blocks IgE-mediated activation and histamine release in human blood basophils. These antiallergic effects of dasatinib may have clinical implications and may point to additional indications for this multifunctional drug. Methods and results: We describe a patient suffering from ASM in whom MC were particularly immature and showed a destructive sarcoma-like growth with infiltration and tumor-formation in the skeleton. Unexpectedly, these immature MC were found to be tryptase-negative cells by routineimmunohistochemistry. In addition, MC did not stain positive for chymase. To establish the correct diagnosis, additional immunohistochemical markers and a highly sensitive staining protocol were applied. In these stains, neoplastic MC were demonstrated to co-express KIT, histidine decarboxylase (HDC), and low amounts of tryptase together with CD25, CD44, and CD63. In addition, the anti-apoptotic molecules Mcl-1 and Bcl-2 were detectable in neoplastic MC. Despite therapy with interferon-alpha and cladribine (2CdA), further progression of the disease into mast cell leukemia developed.
body_text.section: Inhibition of IgE-dependent activation and histamine release in human basophils by Dasatinib

body_text.text: Conclusions: Progression and de-differentiation of MC in SM may be associated with partial loss of MC differentiation antigens including the key marker enzyme tryptase. In such cases, it is of importance to apply additional diagnostic markers and a highly sensitive staining protocol. Aim of this study was to assess "real life data" concerning the clinical outcome of myeloma treatment with B. and comparing them with published data.
body_text.section: Aggressive systemic mastocytosis with sarcomalike growth of mast cells in the skeleton

body_text.text: Methods: Pts. were identified using a data base search of the hospital pharmacies records. All pts. treated with at least one cycle of B. were included in this retrospective analysis. Established risk factors for myeloma (ISS, cytogenetics) were recorded. Besides remission status and overall survival clinical surrogate parameters such as paraprotein, beta-microglobulin, serum creatinin and serum albumin were evaluated. In addition, adverse effects of treatment with B were documented.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Results: A total of 34 pts. were identified (19f / 15m) within the selected time period. 3 patients had a diagnosis different from MM (1 tubulopapillary pleural mesothelioma, 1 DLBCL, 1 LPICC). The subtypes of MMs included IgGkappa (n = 18), IgG-lambda (n = 5), IgA-lambda (n = 3), IgAkappa (n = 2), Bence-Jones-kappa myeloma (n = 3), and Bence-Jones-lambda myeloma (n = 1). The mean pts. age was 63 (range 46-80) years at the time of diagnosis. Two patients received B. within clinical studies, one as 1st line treatment in the VISTA study and one as 2nd line treatment in the Doxil-MMY-3001 study. B. was fairly well tolerated and dose reductions were rarely necessary. Clinical responses were seen in 38.2% (13/34) of the pts. (including CR, VGPR, GPR, and PR). Due to the early treatment phase or ongoing follow-up evaluation of the remission status is still pending in 8 pts. The remaining pts experienced either stable (8/35) or progressive disease (5/35). Updated results on response and survival as well as adverse events of the patients cohort will be presented.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Conclusions: Treatment with B. proved to be effective and safe in every day clinical practice leading to results comparable to published data on multiple myeloma.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: A common polymorphism in the gene for cyclooxygenase-2 (PTGS2 8473T>C) and its association with prostate cancer risk: A population-based study Background: Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is involved in carcinogenesis, immune response suppression, apoptosis inhibition, angiogenesis, tumor cell invasion, and metastasis. The gene for COX-2, designated as PTGS2, carries a common polymorphism at position 8473 in the 3'-untranslated region (PTGS2 8473T>C), which has been associated with susceptibility to malignant disease.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Methods: To investigate the role of the PTGS2 8473T>C polymorphism for prostate cancer, we determined the prevalence of PTGS2 genotypes in 500 men with histologically confirmed prostate cancer and 500 male and age-matched control subjects. Genotypes were determined by a 5'-nuclease assay (TaqMan™). Finally, 95 samples were re-analyzed and results were identical for all samples. Statistical analysis was done using SPSS 11.0 for Windows. Numeric values were analyzed by Student's t-test, proportions of groups were compared by chi2 test. Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals were calculated by logistic regression to estimate the risk for prostate cancer. Threshold for significance was p < 0.05.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Results: Genotype and allele frequencies were not significantly different between prostate cancer patients (TT: 42%, TC: 47%, CC: 11%) and control subjects (TT: 40%, TC: 49%, CC: 11%; p = 0.82). PTGS2 genotypes were furthermore not associated with age at diagnosis of prostate cancer (TT: 68 ± 7 years, TC: 69 ± 7; CC: 69 ± 7; p = 0.13). The study had a statistical power of 0.83 to detect or exclude an odds ratio of 1.7 for the homozygous PTGS2 8473-TT genotype.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Conclusions: We conclude that the PTGS2 8473T>C polymorphism in the gene encoding COX-2 does not contribute to prostate cancer risk.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Are patients with hemochromatosis potential blood donors? G. Leitner 1 , C. Kohl 1 , I. Rach 1 , J. List 1 , M. Horvath 1 , G. Weigel 2 , P. Höcker 1 Background: Hereditary hemochromatosis is one of the most common inherited disorders in Caucasians. A point mutation in the HFE gene is found in 85 to 100 percent of subjects leading to pathological iron metabolism and iron overload. Phlebotomy therapy has been the mainstay of treatment for hemochromatosis for 50 years. According to national and European guidelines the allogeneic use of packed red blood cells (PRBC) collected from hemochromatosis subjects is forbidden. In USA the FDA is less restrictive provided that these PRBCs fulfill the required quality criteria. The aim of this study was to investigate the quality of PRBCs collected from hemochromatosis subjects over a storage period of 42 days.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Methods: We collected 48 PRBCs using apheresis technology from patients who were diagnosed with hemochromatosis but still asymptomatic and therefor fulfilled eligibility criteria for blood donation (n = 8, median age 36 years, range 20 to 53). PRBCs were stored at 4°C (± 2°C) for 42 days To assess the extent of storage lesion we measured metabolic parameters (LDH, free hemoglobin K+, lactate), consumption of glucose, hemolysis and degradation of intracellular purines (ATP, ADP, AMP). Samples were drawn in weekly intervals till the end of shelf life.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Results: The mean haemoglobin (hb) content was 59.2 (± 3.7) g/unit and hemolysis was 0.17% (± 0.1%) at the end of storage. Leukocyte contamination was <1 × 10 6 in all units. The increase of metabolic parameters, as well as the consumption of glucose and the loss of intracellular purines was comparable with PRBCs collected from "normal" subjects.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Conclusions: Freshly collected as well as stored PRBCs from individuals with point mutation in the HFE gene fulfilled national and international required quality criteria for allogeneic blood transfusion. (Hemolysis <0.8% at the end of shelf life, hb content ≥ 40 g/unit, leukocyte contamination <1 × 10 6 / unit). Moreover implementation of hemochromatosis subjects as blood donors would probably counteract seasonal shortages in blood supply. Background: Androgen receptors (AR) are commonly expressed in invasive breast carcinoma. The prognostic significance of AR in survival has been shown in several studies. The influence of antiandrogens already was investigated in a small number of preclinical and clinical studies. Bicalutamide (Casodex ® ) is an oral nonsteroidal antiandrogen which is commonly used in prostate cancer.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Objectivs: The purpose of this study was to investigate the efficacy and tolerability of the antiandrogen Bicalutamide in male and female patients with AR positive metastatic breast cancer (MBC).
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Methods: Between June 2004 and June 2005 one male and six female patients with histologically confirmed metastatic breast cancer were enrolled onto this clinical trial. All patients had received prior chemotherapy and all except one received prior hormonal therapy. Bicalutamide was administered orally at a dose of 50 mg one time daily. Patients were followed every 4 weeks by history, physical examination, haematology and biochemistry. Response evaluation by radiographic measurement was done after eight weeks.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Results: The median age was 62 (range 48-77), median ECOG performance status was 2 (range 1-3). Median number of prior chemotherapy was 3.8 (range 1-6) and median number of prior hormonal therapy was 2.6 (range 0-4). Bicalutamide was well tolerated. There were no adverse events due to study drug. Median duration of Bicalutamide therapy was 8.2 weeks (range 6-12). One response, of 12 weeks duration, was noted. Six patients had progressive disease.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Conclusions: We could not show any positive effect of Bicalutamide on disease control, but we could show the safe administration of antiandrogens in our female patients. Lack of our trial was the advanced disease and poor performance status of study participants. Further studies should investigate antiandrogens in AR positive earlier MBC. Background: Up to now, few data have been collected on the quality of life (QOL) of myeloma patients. Results of a recent study suggest that response to treatment is an important factor in this regard. Our aim was to further investigate the impact of response to treatment on the QOL of myeloma patients undergoing conventional chemotherapy.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Methods: We prospectively collected QOL data using the EORTC QLQ-C30 in a study comparing continuous versus intermittent prednisone plus VMCP in 292 newly diagnosed myeloma patients. A QOL-questionnaire was distributed to each patient at each visit. Using the official EORTC scoring manual, we analyzed the relationship of response to global QOL, all functional scales and the symptom scale fatigue.
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Results: QOL data are available in 186 of 260 evaluable patients. Mean QOL scores during induction therapy were significantly associated with the quality of response achieved. This was still true for the following scales, if patients with progressive disease were excluded from the analysis: global QOL (P 0.02747), fatigue (P 0.00017), role functioning (P 0.04032, Figure) , cognitive functioning (P 0.0224), and emotional functioning (P 0.01274). When QOL at the last visit of induction treatment was analyzed, global QOL (P 0.02273), physical functioning (P 0.01541) and fatigue (P 0.004616) were significantly associated with quality of response. In the case of global QOL and fatigue this was still true when patients with PD were excluded (P 0.04991 and P 0.009635, respectively). Mean physical functioning and cognitive functioning during induction were also inversely correlated with time to first response (P 0.04025 and P 0.04674, respectively).
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Conclusions: Quality of response during induction treatment significantly influences central parameters of QOL including cognitive function in myeloma patients undergoing conventional therapy. If patients with progressive disease are excluded, the magnitude of response is still associated with QOL. Even if survival cannot be prolonged by achieving a better response, myeloma patients might benefit from a better response by having a better quality of life. Results: After consideration of sub-and supermodels, the final model contains main effects of c-IPSS, age, gender and FAB and significant gender*age and age*FAB interactions, expressed by the following formula for the risk ratio: RR = c-ipss*.60 + gender*.24 + age66*.49 + fab_gr*.94 + gender_by_age*-.81 + age_by_fab*-.99
body_text.section: Outcome of patients with multiple myeloma and other malignancies treated with bortezomib at

body_text.text: Conclusions: The simultaneous consideration of c-IPSS, age, gender and FAB confirms the prognostic impact of these characteristics on survival, showing the strongest main effects for c-IPSS and FAB. c-IPSS differentiates well in all gender*age*FAB-subgroups without indications of markedly different importance in specific subgroups ( no significant interactions between c-IPSS and other characteristics). Age and FAB do have strong additional prognostic impact, while gender shows a differential influence, favouring in younger patients males and in older patients females. The age*FAB interaction represents much more pronounced risk differences between RA/RARS vs. RAEB/RAEBt/CMML in younger than in older patients. Cytogenetics as expressed by c-IPSS has strong prognostic impact, comparable in magnitude to that of FAB. Age and gender show weaker main effects, but marked interactions. The fact that prognosis based either only on the c-IPSS or only on age, gender and FAB is clearly less powerful, underlines that c-IPSS and the other considered characteristics add independent explanatory power to a prognostic model and therefore have to be considered jointly. Ergebnisse: Spätestens 2 Stunden nach Beginn der Atemtherapie besserte sich der PaO 2 /FiO 2 Quotient auf Median 305 (229-480), die AF senkte sich auf 15/min (12-16) und spezifische Chemotherapie (Induktiontherapie/Reinduktion bei AML, VAIA bei Sarkom, Carboplatin/Docetaxel bei Adenocarcinom) bzw. antibiotische Therapie konnte fortgeführt bzw. gleichzeitig zur Beatmung eingeleitet werden. Der Patient mit Agranulozytose erhielt Granulozytenkonzentrate, G-CSF und Breitspektrum AB-Therapie bei SIRS und transfusionsassoziertem Lungenversagen. Alle Patienten sprachen auf die krankheitsspezifische Therapie an und konnten nach 3 Tagen Median (1-6) von der nicht invasiven Atemtherapie entwöhnt werden. Durch rechtzeitigen Beginn der nicht invasiven Therapie wurde diese von den Patienten gut toleriert, und es musste kein einziger Patient intubiert werden. Von den Patienten mit akuter myeloischer Leukämie erzielten 2 Patienten eine komplette hämatologische Remission und sind zurzeit noch in Remission. Bei diesen Patienten wäre unter konventioneller Therapie eine Intubation nötig gewesen und in der Regel keine Induktionschemotherapie erfolgt. Der Patient mit Frührezidiv wies einen chemotherapierefraktären Krankheitsverlauf auf, blieb aber in weiterer Folge ohne respiratorische Komplikationen. Auch die Patienten mit Synovialsarkom und Adenokarzinom erzielten eine partielle Remission und konnten ohne respiratorische Probleme entlassen werden. Der Patient mit Agranulozytose und Pneumonie erreichte vollständige Knochenmarksregeneration ohne eine zusätzliche beatmungsasso-ziierte Pneumonie zu erleiden und ist seit 2 Jahren krankheitsfrei.

Sie kann in selektiven Fällen lebensrettend sein. Background: VTD was reported to be an active salvage regimen in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (MM). Since initial results with VTD as frontline therapy were also promising, we used VTD as induction treatment prior to autologous transplantation in MM patients with particularly high tumor burden.
body_text.section: Cytogenetics (c-IPSS), age, gender and FAB classification -joint prognostic impact on survival in MDS

body_text.text: Methods: Velcade was administered at 1.3 mg/m 2 on days 1, 4, 8, and 11; thalidomide was given as a daily dose of 100 mg; dexamethasone (20 mg per os) was given on days 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 9, 11, and 12 . Four cycles were scheduled every 3 weeks.

Results: We here report on three patients (age 36, 38, and 50 years) with newly diagnosed MM and high tumor mass at presentation (patient 1: Bence-Jones kappa MM with 95% plasma cell infiltration, serum free-kappa light-chains 4000 mg/l; patient 2: IgG-kappa MM with serum IgG >9000 mg/dl, bulky plasmacytomas in the iliac bones; patient 3: IgA-lambda MM with 70% plasma cells in the bone marrow, IgA 4500 mg/dl, plasmacytoma in the os sacrum >10 cm in diameter). Genetically, all 3 patients corresponded to the hyperdiploid variant (multiple trisomies, absence of del(13q14) and del(17p13)); patient 1 also had a t(11;14) and gain of chromosome 1q21. VTD resulted in a paraprotein reduction of at least 75% already after cycle 1. Rapid tumor mass reduction was not associated with signs of tumor lysis, and patient 1 had a significant improvement in renal function (serum creatinine from 2.4 to 1.3 mg/dl). After 4 cycles of VTD, patients 1 and 2 achieved a CR including a normal kappa/lambda ratio in the free-light-chain assay (patient 3 still ongoing). Patient 1 has already completed G-CSF primed peripheral stem cell collection and autologous transplantation. Toxicity of VTD was mild (transient nausea and diarrhea in patient 2), in particular no peripheral neuropathy (grade 2 or higher).

Conclusions: Induction treatment with VTD results in an effective tumor mass reduction already within one cycle and should be further evaluated in MM patients in need of rapid disease control. Background: Cell cycle arrest and apoptosis induction are generally regarded as the most important mechanisms by which p53 exerts its tumor suppressive effect. Two main targets have been identified in this respect: (1) p21 Waf1 , as an essential regulator of cell cycle arrest downstream of p53, and (2) PUMA, as the largest single contributor towards p53induced cell death. While deactivation of p53 in mice leads to a 95% incidence of tumors (71% thymic lymphomas) and death within 7 months, the loss p21 Waf1 or PUMA by themselves does not result in a tumorigenic phenotype. Thus, simultaneously disabling these targets may be required to recapitulate the p53-null phenotype in mice.

Methods: We generated mice that were doubly-deficient for Puma and p21 Waf1 . Ex-vivo thymocytes were analysed for resistance to γ-irradiation. Induction of apoptosis was meas-ured by FACS following Annexin V staining and 7aad incorporation. For cell cycle analysis, the absolute number of cells in S-phase was determined by staining for incorporated BrdU, and DNA content was measured using propidium iodide. Mice were followed for the development of spontaneous and radiation-induced tumors and sacrificed when moribund.

Results: Thymocytes isolated from PUMA/ p21 Waf1 double knockout mice (DKO) are resistant to apoptosis and continue to actively cycle and synthesize DNA following γ-irradiation. Thus, DKO ex-vivo thymocytes behave as would be expected from the loss of PUMA and p21 Waf1 . Surprisingly, DKO mice are resistant to the development of spontaneous tumors, with only an 11% tumor incidence after 18 months of age, and none within the lymphoid system. Furthermore, the loss of both PUMA and p21 Waf1 protects mice from the development of thymic lymphomas following whole-body irradiation. Isolation of the lymphoid organs following whole-body irradiation demonstrated little loss of total cellularity within the thymus of DKO mice, again demonstrating, as with the exvivo thymocytes, their resistance to radiation-induced apoptosis. However, despite the lack of this p53-mediated tumor suppressor function, DKO mice remain tumor-free 250 days postirradiation.

Conclusions: Loss of both PUMA and p21 Waf1 protects from cancer development. Additionally, the p53-mediated induction of cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to irradiation and DNA damage do not appear to be essential for tumor suppression. In DKO mice, thymocytes harboring DNA damage induced by radiation treatment are not cleared by apoptosis. Yet this pool of 'mutated' cells are unable to give rise to a tumor clone. Thus, significant and perhaps more important tumor suppression mechanisms still exist despite the loss of both PUMA and p21 Waf1 , or are activated because of it. The urokinase system has originally been implicated to assist the angiogenic process by it's proteolytic properties, thereby supporting new blood vessel formation in malignant diseases. It is now becoming increasingly evident that uPA additionally elicits many pro-angiogenic responses like differentiation, proliferation and cell migration in a non-proteolytic fashion via induction of intracellular signal transduction. Thereby, high malignancy in certain tumors has been shown to be accompanied by high levels of urokinase secretion.

In this study we demonstrate that in endothelial cells uPA protects against apoptosis by transcriptional upregulation of inhibitor of apoptosis proteins (IAPs), among them most prominently the X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein (XIAP). In contrast to canonical growth factors, like vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), uPA elicits anti-apoptosis independently of the PI3-kinase pathway. uPA-induced cell survival is dependent on the type of extracellular matrix used indicating the involvement of integrin adhesion receptors. Thereby, uPA induces phosphorylation of the CDC42 downstream effector p21-activated kinase 1 (PAK1), which leads to IkappaB kinase alpha (IKKa) phosphorylation, a prerequisite for NFkappaB activation. Blocking NFkappaB by using the specific NFkappaB inhibitor BAY 11-7082 or by adenoviralmediated overexpression of its inhibitor, IkB, inhibits uPAinduced XIAP expression as well as uPA-induced cell survival. Downregulating XIAP expression by small interfering RNA techniques significantly reduces cell survival efficiencies of uPA in endothelial cells.
From these data we conclude that uPA activation, which is a main player in endothelial cell migration and invasion, provides an additional, PI3-kinase independent cell survival mechanism.

Clinical scale propagation of functional cord blood MSC in a humanized system A. Reinisch 1,4 , C. Bartmann 1, 2, 4 Methods: We analyzed isolation and proliferative potential of human UCB-MSC as compared to BM-MSC under optimized ex vivo culture conditions. We further investigated the impact of human platelet lysate (HPL) as an alternative to replace FBS for clinical scale expansion of MSC. Progenitor cell function was determined by CFU-F assays and correlated to proliferative senescence. MSC functions were tested in hematopoiesis support, vascular regenerative and immune modulation potency assay.

Results: MSC could be reproducibly propagated from UCB with and without FBS. MSC propagation was effective in 46% of UCB samples compared to 100% of BM samples. Once established, the proliferation kinetics of UCB-MSC did not differ significantly from that of BM-MSC under optimized culture conditions resulting in >50 population doublings after only 10 weeks. A clinical quantity of 100 million MSC could be obtained from UCB-MSC despite minute primary cell amounts. Immune suppression and vascular regenerative function in vitro could be shown for UCB-MSC propagated under both culture conditions. Ex vivo expansion of UCB-derived CD34 + /CD38 + hematopoietic progenitors and was more efficient with HPL compared to FBS cultured UCB-MSC.
Conclusions: We demonstrate for the first time that human MSC can be obtained and propagated to a clinical quantity from UCB in a completely FBS-free system although.

Surprisingly, our data argue against a generally superior proliferative potential of UCB-MSC compared to adult BM-MSC. The efficient propagation of UCB-derived CD34 + /CD38 -HSC encourages further studies to develop effective strategies for UCB-SC expansion for adult patients.

Einstellung zur Reanimation von Patienten mit fortgeschrittener, unheilbarer Erkrankung bei Aufnahme auf einer Palliativstation -eine retrospektive Studie V. Requat 1 , B. Hammerl 1 , C. Geissler 1 , G. Fischer 2 , K. Geissler 1,2 1 5. Medizinische Abteilung mit Onkologie und Palliativstation, Krankenhaus Hietzing, Wien, Österreich; 2 Ludwig Boltzmann Institut für klinische Onkologie, Wien, Österreich Grundlagen: Die weitestgehende Berücksichtigung der Patientenautonomie (mutmaßlicher Patientenwille) ist einer der zentralen Grundsätze in der Palliativmedizin. Aus diesem Grund ist es von besonderem Interesse, die Einstellung der Patienten auf einer Palliativstation zur Reanimation zu untersuchen.

Methodik: Von insgesamt 365 Fragebögen, die bei Aufnahme auf der Palliativstation einer onkologischen Abteilung im Zuge eines Assessments durch den jeweils zuständigen Stationsarzt ausgefüllt wurden, waren 294 im Hinblick auf die Frage nach einer allfälligen Reanimation auswertbar. Die Fragebögen enthielten neben Fragen betreffend Einstellung der PatientInnen zu medizinischen Maßnahmen und Reanimation auch Fragen, mit denen die physische, psychische und soziale Situation/Befindlichkeit evaluiert wurde.

Ergebnisse: Als Ergebnis zeigte sich, dass 44 % der Befragten eine allfällige Reanimation ablehnten während 56 % keinen Einwand gegen diese Maßnahme äußerten. In beiden Gruppen zeigten sich keine statistisch signifikanten Unterschiede im Hinblick auf die untersuchten Dimensionen psychische Befindlichkeit, physische Befindlichkeit, Hilfsbedürftigkeit bei Körperpflege, Mobilität, Schmerzen, Übelkeit, Dyspnoe und Schwäche. Die Gruppen unterschieden sich ebenfalls nicht in Bezug auf religiöses Bekenntnis, Wohnsituation und Alter.

Schlussfolgerungen: Unsere Ergebnisse zeigen, dass etwas weniger als die Hälfte der Patienten, die auf unserer Palliativstation aufgenommen werden, eine allfällige Reanimation ablehnen. Im Setting unseres Assessments (strukturiertes Interview) konnten kein Einfluss des physischen, psychischen und sozialen Status auf diese Entscheidung festgestellt werden. Mögliche Einflussfaktoren auf das Ergebnis unserer Auswertungen inkludieren unterschiedlicher Befragungsmodus, vorbestehende psychopharmakologische und medizinische Therapie, unterschiedliche Phasen der Krankheitsverarbeitung, unterschiedlicher Wissensstand in Bezug auf die Grunderkrankung, soziale Erwünschtheit und divergente Vorstellungen über Reanimation. Zukünftige Studien sollten diesen möglichen Einflussfaktoren Rechnung tragen. Background: Colony-forming units of endothelial progenitor cells ("CFU-EC") have been introduced as a powerful biological marker for vascular function and cumulative cardiovascular risk. The level of "CFU-EC" has even been described to predict the occurrence of cardiovascular events and death from cardiovascular causes and may identify patients at increased cardiovascular risk. The precise mechanisms underlying "CFU-EC" formation and their cellular composition are unknown.

Methods: We performed detailed subtractive "CFU-EC" analyses in blood samples of 18 healthy volunteers. The impact of various blood cell types and kinetics of protein and gene expression were studied by cell sorting, flow cytometry, quantitative RT-PCR and full genome microarray analyses. "CFU-EC"-derived soluble factors were measured by multiplex cytokine display and functionally tested during endothelial network formation.

Results: "CFU-EC" contained more than 99% CD45 + nucleated hematopoietic cells mainly comprising T cells and monocytes admixed with B and NK cells. Interestingly, purified T-cells plus monocytes were able to form "CFU-EC" clusters. The complete lack of colony formation after depletion of T cells or monocytes was contrasted by an unaffected "CFU-EC" formation after depletion of CD34 + progenitors. Gene expression profiling revealed an activation of various immune function-related biological processes but no changes in pathways assigned to angiogenesis. Soluble factors derived from "CFU-EC" cultures supported the vascular regenerative function of Endothelial Progenitor Cells (EPC) in vitro.

Conclusions: Unravelling "CFU-EC" formation as a result of a functional crosstalk between T cells and monocytes shifts expectations on vascular regenerative medicine. The data support a switch from a sole view on circulating EPC towards models that recognize the contribution of immune cell function during vascular regeneration. Background: Yttrium-90 (Y-90) Ibritumomab Tiuxetan (Zevalin) is a murine anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody devel-oped for radioimmunotherapeutic targeting of CD20+ lymphoma cells. Using Zevalin, a localised cytotoxic radiation is administered to malignant cells with only minimal side effects on other organs.Methods: 38 patients with relapsed or refractory Non Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL) were treated in this cohort. 26 patients had relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma, 8 patients had relapsed or refractory diffuse large B cell lymphoma, 2 patients suffered from Immunocytoma and 1 patient had mantle cell lymphoma. The median age was 63 years. 35 patients were extensively pre-treated with a median of 13 prior therapy cycles (range 3-19). In 3 patients Zevalin was administered as first line therapy. The Zevalin treatment regimen consisted of pre-treatment with Rituximab (250 mg/m^2 intravenously on day 1 and 8) to deplete peripheral blood B cells followed by Zevalin infusion on day 8. A mean of 1067 MBq (range 680-2040) Y-90 Ibritumomab Tiuxetan (Yatrics-Zevalin, Schering AG) was administered. Remission was evaluated 3 month after Zevalin therapy.Results: So far the response to treatment could be evaluated for 33/38 patients. The overall response rate was 76%. 58% (19/33) achieved complete remission/complete remission unconfirmed (CR/CRu), 18% (6/33) achieved partial remission and 24% (6/33) showed no or only minimal response to treatment (5/6 succumb to disease and 1/6 had progressive disease). The response of 5 out of 38 patients is not yet evaluated. 16 out of the 19 CR/CRu are still in CR/CRu with a median duration of response of 16 months (range 5-27). Two patients relapsed and one patient in CR died due to myocardial infarction. The main side effect was thrombocytopenia followed by mild leukocytopenia and anemia. There were no significant affects on other organ function.
Conclusions: Zevalin is an effective and promising therapeutic option especially in elderly and extensively pre-treated patients with CD20+ NHL with only minimal side effects.

Differential CD44 methylation in haematologic malignancies J. D. Rudzki, B. Kircher, A. Amberger, G. Gastl, R. Stauder Immunobiology and Stem Cell Laboratory, Division of Hematology and Oncology, Department of Internal Medicine, Medical University of Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria

cite_spans.text: Rudzki, B. Kircher, A. Amberger, G. Gastl, R. Stauder

body_text.text: Background: CD44 comprises a family of class I transmembrane glycoproteins, which exists in several isoforms. This surface molecule has been involved in various processes such as tumorigenesis, haematopoiesis and inflammation. The standard CD44 isoform is expressed on all types of mature blood cells, on the majority of mononuclear bone marrow precursors and on all CD34+ haematopoietic progenitor cells. Changes in expression of CD44 have been shown during the early differentiation of primitive haematopoietic cells as well as in certain aggressive lymphomas. Elevated expression of CD44 has been reported from patients with acute and chronic myeloid leukaemia (AML, CML) or a late form of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

Methylation of CpG sites in the promoter region has been often described as a potent way of restricting gene expression, called "gene silencing". A small part of the total DNA com-prises CpG islands, in which CpG dinucleotides occur at a higher frequency than in the rest of the genome. These regions are normally unmethylated. When methylated, CpG islands in gene-regulatory (promoter) sequences may repress transcription.

Aim: The aim of this study was to gain information about the methylation pattern of CD44 and furthermore to evaluate if alterations in methylation represent a regulatory mechanism of CD44 expression. Methylated regulatory sequences are discussed in diverse malignancies like colorectal or gastric carcinoma but often without any information about the percentage of methylated versus unmethylated CpGs. This implicates the question after a consistent relationship between methylating/demethylating events and expression and needs to be further elucidated.

Methods: Genomic DNA was isolated from three cell line and blood samples from an AML and an MDS patient, converted by bisulfite modification and analysed by methylationspecific polymerase chain reaction. Cloning and subsequent sequencing the amplificates was performed to an analyze the methylation pattern within and at the boundary of exon 1 of CD44, an approximately 700 bp region.

Results: All three cell lines showed a diverse methylation pattern of CD44. The lowest amount of methylation was observed in the CML cell line K-562 (2%). An increased percentage of methylated CpGs was displayed in the AML cell line , whereas the highest CD44 methylation was registered in the lymphoma cell line U-937.

Conclusions: These analyses reveal a differential pattern of CD44 methylation in haematological malignancies, displaying in general a lower percentage of methylation sites as compared to neuroblastoma (100%) or prostate cancer (30-100%). The analysis of the patients' methylation pattern and the corresponding CD44 expression are currently under investigation.

Clinical scale expansion of MSC with human platelet lysate K. Schallmoser 1,4 , C. Bartmann 1, 2, 4

We developed a new model for the FBS-free propagation of human MSC for clinical application. We analyzed the capacity of different preparations of human platelet lysate (HPL) to replace FBS for clinical scale MSC production with cytomic, proteomic and genomic technology.

Results: Using a two-step good manufacturing practice (GMP) procedure for MSC propagation, we found that HPL can fully replace FBS as a growth factor supplement for clinical scale MSC preparation. HPL was reproducibly more efficient than FBS and supported the outgrowth of >400 million MSC from <0.4 million primary MSC (derived from <2mL bone marrow aspiration within 10 days ex vivo) within less than 4 weeks of culture. Although morphologically distinct, HPL-MSC and FBS-MSC did not differ regarding their CD13 + /29 + /73 + /90 + /105 + /146 + /34 -/45 -/133 -/HLA-AB + immunophenotype. Multiplex analyses allowed delineating a distinct cytokine and growth factor profile. Whole transcriptome microarray analyses revealed a differential regulation of >300 genes after only one cycle of human as compared to bovine growth factor stimulation. Allogeneic HPL-MSC infusion in an intent to treat refractory GvHD was feasible and without infusion-related side effects.

Conclusions: This new FBS-free procedure for clinical scale MSC propagation will largely facilitate rational clinical testing of MSC based therapies. Replacing FBS with HPL excludes bovine prion, viral and zoonose contamination of the stem cell product. Based on this protocol a clinical trial for the treatment of steroid-refractory GvHD with HPL-MSC will be initiated. Background: Determination of HER-2/neu expression is routinely performed in primary breast cancer tissue in order to assess the patient's prognosis and the adjuvant treatment plan. The purpose of this study was to examine, whether neoadjuvant chemotherapy influences the HER-2/neu status of breast cancer tissue.

Methods: For 80 patients with breast cancer, treated with neoadjuvant anthracycline-based chemotherapy, the immunohistochemical tissue scores of HER-2/neu were determined in the biopsy samples obtained before initiation of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and in the surgically removed tumors after completion of the neoadjuvant treatment. Membrane immunoreactivity and membrane staining patterns were evaluated using the HercepTest™ with a scoring system of 0 to 3+.

body_text.text: Results: Changes of the HER-2/neu expression scores between biopsy sample and the post-chemotherapy tumor sample have been observed in 32 (40%) patients. In 2 (2.5%) patients HER-2/neu score changed from 0 to 1+, in 19 (23.8%) patients from 1+ to 0, in 2 (2.5%) patients from 1+ to 2+, in 5 (6.3%) patients from 2+ to 0, in 3 (3.8%) patients from 2+ to 3+ and in one (1.3%) patient from 3+ to 0. Case reports: Four patients (3 females, 1 male, age at diagnosis 26-61 years) with severe idiopathic AITP with a late spontaneous remission are described. All had serum antibodies to platelet GP IIb/IIIa, two patients had a lupus anticoagulant (LA). All were refractory to initial steroid therapy, two to SE (two refused SE), one to 3 courses (2-6 months) of low dose azathioprine (20 years prior to remission) and the other one to a 2 months course of cyclosporine (4 years prior to remission). All patients received low dose continuous or intermittent steroids. Six to 31 years after diagnosis these patients achieved a spontaneous CR (n = 3) or partial remission (n = 1) unrelated to any specific second or third line treatment, CR are sustained for 0.5+ to 9+ years. GP IIb/IIIa antibodies disappeared in two patients in haematological remission (but were detectable on platelets in one of them). The LA disappeared in one patient.

body_text.text: Conclusions: Few cases are reported on spontaneous late remission in children after more than 5 years disease duration; only 5 adult patients with severe AITP have been described earlier who failed SE and achieved late spontaneous remissions after 5-12 years. Our data indicate that spontaneous remissions may occur in AITP even after a long duration of the disease in a small number of patients. We estimate that such late spontaneous remissions occur in about 1% of AITP patients.

body_text.text: Poorly differentiated neuroendocrine tumours of non lung origin -a single institution experience Background: Poorly differentiated neuroendocrine tumours (NET) mostly arise in the lung (SCLC) but may also develop in other parts of the body. There are a number of treatment studies in SCLC, but reports on treatment of NET of non lung origin are limited.

body_text.text: Methods: We report our experience in patients with poorly differentiated neuroendocrine tumours of non lung origin who were found in a database that contains more than 10.000 patients with malignancy. 15 patients with poorly differentiated neuroendocrine tumours were collected.

body_text.text: Results: Median age was 55 years (range 45-81). 5 patients had a localized stage, 10 patients presented with advanced stage. Regions of tumour manifestation included liver (n = 4), bone marrow (n = 3), lymph node (n = 3), pancreas (n = 1), larynx (n = 1), stomach (n = 1), esophagus (n = 1), bone (n = 1), cerebrum (n = 1), uterus (n = 1), urine bladder (n = 1) and nose (n = 1). 5 patients with localized stage had local treatment (surgery [n = 4] and/or irradiation [n = 2]) as well as adjuvant chemotherapy (n = 4). 2 of these patients died after 10 and 17 months, 3 patients are still living 4-53 months following diagnosis. 11 patients with advanced disease (10 patients with primary advanced disease and 1 patient with relapse following local treatment) received first line chemotherapy (6 cisplatin based, 5 anthracyclin based chemotherapy). The remission rate achieved was 36.3% (3 PR, 1 CR). The median duration of response was 5 months (4-9) and the median survival 7 (4-27) months.

body_text.text: Conclusions: We confirm that poorly differentiated neuroendocrine tumours of non lung origin are chemosensitive. However the prognosis of advanced stage disease is still poor due to relapse. Some patients with localized disease may achieve long term survival. Background: For the treatment of tumor patients not only the somatic diagnostics, but also the considerations of psychological and social features are of importance. A timely recognising and supporting of those patients with psycho-social burden represents an essential improvement of the quality of life of tumor patients. The aim of the study was the observation of the subjective somatic and psychological burden, as well as the indication for psycho-social care for patients at the oncology-unit at the hospital in Oberwart, Austria, with the help of the questionnaire Psychoonkologische Basisdokumentation (PoBado).
body_text.section: Influence of neoadjuvant chemotherapy on the

body_text.text: Methods: In connection with the psycho-oncologic first conversation 123 patients were evaluated in the time period between February 2005 and October 2006. The first part of the questionnaire comprises the most important socio-demographic and medical parameters of the patients. The second part comprises somatic burden (4 items) and the psychological burden (8 items). The experiences of the patients were rated on a 5-point Likert scale. Three further items contain possible additional loads. The time window to be judged included the last 3 days before the stationary stay. The evaluation of the data, as well as the comparison with the referencepopulation took place through the PoBado-Projektzentrale at the TU-Munich.

body_text.text: Results: The examined population was to 60% in an advanced disease stage and exhibited in 52 percent additional illnesses. Only 29% of the patients were not under tumor-specific therapy in the last two months. The sum-score of the somatic trouble was 6.2 and this was slightly increased in comparison to the reference-population of 5.5 (n = 4596). In the case of the psychological complaints a sum value of 10 resulted. This corresponded to that of the reference-population (10.2). Incriminating problems in the families and circle of friends emerged in 30.9%, economic and/or vocational problems in 7%. The indication for professional psycho-social support was determined in 61.8% (59.9% in the reference-population).

body_text.text: Conclusions: For the treatment of patients with tumor-illness more frequently also their subjective feeling (in psychological, somatic and social regard) should be considered systematically. This is true for the doctor/patient-relationship, as well as for the indication for accompanied therapy-measures or the evaluation of the new therapies through clinical trials. The up to now used instruments Karnofsky-Index or Spitzer-Index, refer exclusively on physical functional ability. With help of the questionnaire of PoBado we could find a slightly elevated score for somatic trouble and a high need of psychosocial care-demand of 61.8% in our collective. Background: Clinical observations and recent experimental data suggest an anti-angiogenic effect of the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib independent from its anti-tumor activity.
body_text.section: Influence of neoadjuvant chemotherapy on the

body_text.text: Aim: To assess bortezomib's anti-angiogenic effects in vitro and in vivo and to characterise the exact mechanism of angiogenesis inhibition.

Methods: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and circulating endothelial progenitor cells (CEPs) were isolated from umbilical cords and peripheral blood, respectively. All experiments were performed separately for both cell types. Cell viability was determined in WST-1 assays, apoptosis was assessed using DAPI staining, flow cytometry and cell cycle analysis. Tube formation capacity was examined with Matrigel ® assays, cell migration was investigated using standard Boyden chambers. For assessment of anti-angiogenic effects in vivo, Matrigel ® containing VEGF was injected subcutaneously into C57BL mice. Bortezomib (1 mg/kg q72 hours) was administered intraperitoneally. After 14 days mice were sacrificed, Matrigel ® implants were removed and microvessels counted using Isolectin B4.

Results: In subconfluent cell cultures pre-incubation with bortezomib over 24 hours significantly reduced cell viability in a dose-dependent fashion (EC50: 5 ng/ml). Moreover, bortezomib (5-10 ng/ml) induced apoptosis in proliferating HUVECs and CEPs involving the activation of caspase-3. In sublethal doses (e.g., 1 ng/ml), bortezomib exerted a cell cycle arrest in phase G1. In contrast, no apoptosis induction was detectable in confluent endothelial cell cultures even with bortezomib concentrations as high as 10 ng/ml. Tube formation on Matrigel ® and endothelial cell migration were also inhibited significantly in a dose-dependent fashion (1-10 ng/ml). In vitro observations were confirmed in our in vivo model where VEGF-induced sprouting of subcutaneous microvessels into the Matrigel ® matrix was abrogated by systemic administration of bortezomib.

Conclusions: Our study shows that bortezomib displays profound anti-angiogenic properties in vitro and in vivo. This effect is most pronounced in proliferating endothelial cells and involves apoptosis induction via caspase-3.
Quality of response and survival in myeloma patients undergoing conventional chemotherapy K. Strasser-Weippl, H. Ludwig

Background: The relationship between response and survival in multiple myeloma has been discussed in several studies with conflicting outcomes. In particular, it is unclear whether the magnitude of M-protein reduction apart from a complete remission is relevant for patients undergoing conventional chemotherapy.
body_text.section: 1st Medical Department, Wilhelminen Hospital, Vienna, Austria

body_text.text: Methods: We retrospectively analyzed data from a study evaluating continuous versus intermittent prednisone and polychemotherapy with VMCP in 292 myeloma patients. Response was determined according to EBMT criteria and correlated with survival. In addition, we conducted a Medline literature review on studies analyzing the relationship of response and survival in myeloma patients treated with conventional chemotherapy.
body_text.section: 1st Medical Department, Wilhelminen Hospital, Vienna, Austria

body_text.text: Results: In our own cohort, response was significantly associated with survival in 260 evaluable patients (P 8.91 × 10 -8 ). If patients with PD were excluded, only those reaching a CR did significantly better than all other patients (P 0.0425). In a multivariate analysis including response, stage at diagnosis, age, gender and M-protein type, only response, stage and age were prognostically relevant (P-values 6.3 × 10 -6 , 0.014, and 0.0038, respectively). In the literature review, we identified 15 trials published since 1967, including 2252 patients which fit to the criteria described above. The trials showed significant heterogeneity regarding treatment setting, treatment regimens, and length of treatment. The magnitude of paraprotein reduction required for a response ranged from 25% to 75%. In all studies, patients with progressive disease were included in the non-responder category. Overall, 11 of the 17 analyses (2 studies included 2 analyses each) showed a significant relationship between response and survival, while in 5 of the 6 other analyses the association did not reach statistical significance. In one study, the survival of responders was 26.5 months versus 29 months in non-responders (n.s.). A compre-hensive table including trial characteristics and results will be presented.
body_text.section: 1st Medical Department, Wilhelminen Hospital, Vienna, Austria

body_text.text: Conclusions: When response defined by paraprotein reduction is compared to non-response including SD and PD, it is associated with prolonged survival in myeloma patients undergoing conventional chemotherapy. The magnitude of paraprotein reduction required to translate into longer survival remains undefined by the available data. Background: The XPD gene is involved in nucleotide excision repair of DNA by opening the DNA around the damage. It also takes part in the initiation of RNA transcription by RNA polymerase II. The Lys751Gln polymorphism of this gene is suspected to be a predisposing factor for NSCLC development as polymorphic variants of this gene have different repair efficiency. The aim of this study was to establish the frequencies of the polymorphic XPD Lys751Gln genotypes in Polish population and to assess the associated risk of NSCLC development.
body_text.section: 1st Medical Department, Wilhelminen Hospital, Vienna, Austria

body_text.text: Materials and methods: The study group included 162 NSCLC patients (13 females and 149 males) who underwent curative pulmonary resection between the year 1996 and 2000. The control group included 485 healthy subjects. DNA was extracted from frozen blood samples. XPD Lys751Gln polymorphism was evaluated by PCR-RFLP based methods.

Results: The frequencies of XPD gene Lys751Gln genotypes (Lys/Lys, Lys/Gln, Gln/Gln) in NSCLC patients were 38.3%, 43.2% and 18.5%, respectively and 37.1%, 46.2% and 16.7% respectively in healthy controls. The proportion of Gln allele carriers vs Lys homozygotes was insignificantly lower in the NSCLC group than in controls (61.7% vs. 62.9%, p = 0.86).

Conclusions: These results indicate that XPD (gln751 variant) polymorphism does not carry increased risk of NSCLC development. Neutrophil granulocytes are short-lived leukocytes that have to be constantly regenerated from myeloid progenitors. Retinoid-X-receptor-alpha (RXRα) is the predominant RXR protein in myeloid cells. RXRα is able to heterodimerize with other nuclear receptor (NR) family members or form signalcompetent homodimers. RXRα partner availability regulated by intracellular RXRα abundance is thought to determine NR signaling. However its regulation in primary neutrophil versus monocyte differentiation remained uncharacterized. Here we show that myeloid progenitors express RXRα protein at sustained high levels during M-CSF-induced monopoiesis. In sharp contrast, RXRα is downregulated during G-CSF induced late-stage neutrophil differentiation. Ectopic RXRα inhibited G-CSF-dependent cell proliferation of granulocyte progenitors as well as their differentiation to late stage LF+ neutrophils in a serum-free culture model of CD34+ human progenitors. Furthermore, ectopic RXRα was sufficient to redirect G-CSF stimulated progenitors to monocytes. In line with its elevation in monocytes, RXRα failed to inhibit, but rather augmented M-CSF-dependent monocyte generation. Functional genetic interference with RXRα signaling in hematopoietic progenitor/stem cells using a "dominant-negative" RXRα promoted the generation of late stage granulocytes in vivo and in vitro. Therefore, downregulation of RXRα protein is required for neutrophil generation. This differential regulation of RXRα protein expression is determined by granulocyte versus monocyte cytokine signals.

Relative numbers of CD4+ effector memory T-cells negatively predict for reduced treatmentfree survival in B-CLL I. Tinhofer, L. Weiss, G. Rubenzer, C. Holler, R. Greil Laboratory of Immunological and Molecular Cancer Research (LIMCR), 3rd Medical Department of Hematology, Oncology, Hemostaseology, Rheumatology and Infectiology, Paracelsus Private Medical University, Salzburg, Austria Background: As major mechanism of tumor immune escape both the suppression of tumor-controlling immune cells and the outgrowth of cells with tumor-supportive functions has been postulated. In the current study we addressed the question whether an interaction of T-cell subsets with the course of disease exists in B-CLL and whether this could be explained by a selection toward tumor-supportive T-cells within the Tcell compartment of B-CLL patients.

Methods: Flow cytometric analysis was applied to determine relative distribution and absolute numbers of naive (T naive ), central memory (T CM ), effector memory (T EM ) and effector T-cells (T EMRA ) in peripheral blood samples of B-CLL patients (n = 175) and healthy age-and sex-matched controls (n = 67). Relative numbers of T-cell subsets were correlated with treatment-free and overall survival. Functional studies were performed to reveal potential survival signals delivered to B-CLL cells by specific T-cell subsets.

Results: A significant skewing of the CD4+ T-cell pool with a decrease in CD4+ Tnaive (p < .0001) in favor of an increase in T EM (p < .0001) was observed in the CD4+ T-cell pool which was more prominent than in the CD8+ T-cell pool, occurred very early in clinical course and was significantly more pronounced in progressive as compared to stable patients. Univariate analysis identified a relative number of >15% T EM cells within the CD4+ T-cell pool as risk parameter for reduced treatment-free survival (hazard ratio: 2.5, 95% CI 1.2-4.9, p = .01), and it retained significance even when absence/presence of p53 aberrations were included in the multivariate analysis (hazard ratio: 2.7, 95% CI 1.1-6.3, p = .01). Interleukin-4 could be identified as potential mediator of CD4+ T-cell-induced survival of B-CLL cells in vitro.

Conclusions: We could demonstrate a significant influence of CD4+ T EM cells on the course of disease in B-CLL. Functional studies in the future are required to elucidate the exact molecular mechanisms of this interaction.

Fallbericht: 51/2 Jahre, anhaltende, komplette Remission eines metastasierten gastrointestinalen Stromatumors unter Glivec ® E. Ulsperger 1,3 , E. Gaisfuss 2 , P. Bratusch-Marrain 2 , K. Geissler 1,3 1 5. Medizinische Abteilung, Onkologie, Krankenhaus Hietzing, Wien, Österreich; 2 Interne Abteilung, Waldviertel-Klinikum Horn, Horn, Österreich; 3 Ludwig Boltzmann Institut für klinische Onkologie Lainz, Wien, Österreich Grundlagen: Gastrointestinale Stromatumore (GIST) zählen zu den Spindelzelltumoren und unterscheiden sich von Leiomyomen und Schwannomen durch die Expression von CD117 (c-kit). Seit nunmehr 6 Jahren steht für GISTs mit dem Tyrosin-kinase-Inhibitor Glivec ® , eine spezifische Therapie zur Verfügung.

Methodik (Fallbericht): Ein 62-jähriger Mann wurde im August 2001 mit den Symptomen einer Harnverhaltung mit Restharn, Nephropathie, Diabetes mellitus (insulinpflichtig seit 1981), und 20 kg Gewichtsverlust stationär aufgenommen. Klinisch wurde eine massive Lebervergrößerung (5 Querfinger) mit entsprechend erhöhten Leberparametern und eine große tumoröse abdominale Raumforderung -einem Darmkonvolut entsprechend -gefunden. In der Computertomographie (CT) fanden sich den gesamten peritonealen Raum ausfüllende Auflagerungen, großteils die Darmschlingen umscheidend sowie hypodense Leberherde (2 cm groß). In einer U-Schall-gezielten Biopsie konnte ein c-kit positiver Spindelzelltumor, einem GIST entsprechend, nachgewiesen werden.

Ergebnisse: Aufgrund des bekannt schlechten Ansprechens auf zytostatische Therapie leiteten wir ambulant eine Therapie mit Glivec ® (400 mg täglich) ein. Bereits nach den ersten vier Wochen zeigte sich klinisch sowohl eine deutliche Verbesserung des Allgemeinzustandes als auch eine Tumorreduktion. Nach dem 2. Monat dieser Therapie konnte die klini-sche Besserung in der CT-Kontrolle verifiziert werden (50 % Rückgang). Diese Entwicklung setzte sich im Laufe der weiteren Therapie fort und in weiterer Folge zeigte die CT eine fast komplette Remission. Parallel dazu kam es zu einer Normalisierung der Leberparameter. Als Nebenwirkungen wurden von dem Patienten anfänglich leichte Lidödeme und Knöchelödeme bemerkt. Diese besserten sich trotz Fortsetzung der Glivec ® -Therapie ohne Dosisreduktion. Nach 18 Monaten Therapie kam es einmalig zu einer gastralen Ulkusblutung, die transfusionsbedürftig war. Eine "second look" Operation lehnt der Patient bis dato ab. Der Patient ist im sechsten Jahr der Therapie, mit 400 mg Glivec ® täglich, beschwerdefrei.
Schlussfolgerungen: Die Fortsetzung der Therapie in unveränderter Dosis ist geplant.

Dickkopf-homolog-3 is required for vasculogenesis and is overexpressed in tumor vessels of aggressive human gliomas G. Untergasser 1 , M. Zimmermann 1 , J. Kern 1 , H. Rumpold 2 , M. Hermann 3 , G. Gastl 1 , E. Gunsilius 1 Background: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is produced in neoplastic cells in various myeloid malignancies including acute and chronic myeloid leukemias. VEGF is considered to play an important pathogenetic role as a mediator of leukemia-associated angiogenesis. In addition, VEGF has been described to directly stimulate leukemia cell growth through specific receptors and thus may act as an autocrine growth regulator. However, although various receptors for VEGF have been identified, little is known about expression and distribution of these receptors on neoplastic cells in the various myeloid leukemias.

Methods: In the present study, we have examined expression of VEGF and of five different VEGF receptors (Flt-1, Flk-1/KDR, Flt-4, neuropilin-1 = NRP-1, neuropilin-2 = NRP-2) in neoplastic myeloid cells including cell lines (HL60, U937, KG1, KG1a, K562, KU812, EOL-1, HMC-1) as well as primary neoplastic cells obtained from 28 patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), 14 with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), 9 with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML), 3 with chronic eosinophilic leukemia (CEL), and 3 patients with mast cell leukemia (MCL, n = 1) or systemic mastocytosis (SM, n = 2). Expression of VEGF-and VEGF receptor mRNA was analyzed by RT-PCR and expression of the VEGF protein by immunocytochemistry.

Results: Confirming previous data, VEGF mRNA and the VEGF protein were detectable in most patients and most cell lines examined. In all patients and all cell lines tested, neoplastic cells were found to express transcripts for NRP-1. In addition, neoplastic cells also co-expressed NRP-2 in most cases. By contrast, transcripts for Flt-1, KDR, and Flt-4 were expressed variably in leukemic cells. In some cases, a correlation between VEGR expression and the type of leukemia was found. Likewise, in AML, KDR mRNA was found to be expressed primarily in blast cells in patients with FAB M4 (7/9; 78%) and M7 (2/2). Transcripts for KDR were also detected in 2/3 patients with mast cell disease, but were not detected in patients with CEL. Interestingly, Flt-1 mRNA levels were found in the patient with MCL and in the MCL cell line HMC-1, but neither in patients with SM or CEL nor in the CEL-related cell line EOL-1. Another interesting observation was that Flt-4 mRNA was expressed in neoplastic monocytes in a majority of all CMML patients examined (7/9; 78%). Flt-1, KDR, and Flt-4 were found to be expressed variably in the myeloid cell lines examined without a clear correlation to the type of leukemia.

Conclusions: VEGF receptors including the co-receptors NRP-1 and NRP-2, are frequently expressed in neoplastic cells in various myeloid neoplasms including AML, CML, CMML, CEL, and MCL. The notion that these neoplastic cells express and secrete VEGF in a constitutive manner and can express additional VEGFR favors the hypothesis that VEGF may act as autocrine growth regulator in some of these malignancies.

Palonosetron -cost-effective prevention of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) E. Walter 1 , S. Zehetmayr 1 , G. Achzet 2 1 IPF Institute for Pharmaeconomic Research, Vienna, Austria; 2 CSC Pharmaceuticals Handels GmbH, Bisamberg, Austria

Background: Despite ongoing improvements in supportive cancer therapy, nausea and vomiting are among the most inconvenient adverse events experienced by cancer patients treated with cytotoxic chemotherapy. Various antiemetic drugs are available for prevention of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). While conventional 5HT 3 -receptor antagonists obviously represent a major milestone in the management of acute CINV, prevention of delayed nausea and vomiting on days 2-5 requires repeat dosing. Palonosetron, a novel 5HT 3 -receptor antagonist, has both a longer plasma halflife and a higher binding affinity. With a single IV dose of 0.25 mg, Palonosetron provides an optimal prevention of acute nausea and vomiting and an improved efficacy in the delayed phase. The objective of this pharmacoeconomic analysis was to economically assess two antiemetic treatment options: palonosetron (0.25 mg IV d1) versus ondansetron (8 mg IV plus 8 mg PO d1 + 2 × 8 mg PO d2-5).

Methods: This comparative economic evaluation of palonosetron versus ondansetron was made using a decision model: the direct medical costs (including medication costs and the cost of medical care provided by doctors in private practice, hospital outpatient clinics and inpatient hospital care) and the effectiveness (complete response (CR) after 0-120 hours) of the two treatment options were captured and modeled for the 5-day observation period of interest. Cost-effectiveness analyses were performed from the perspectives of the health care system, hospitals, and statutory health insurance funds.

Results: From the health care system's perspective, the cost per successfully treated patient for the 5-day observation period was 542.14 EUR for palonosetron. The cost of ondansetron use over the same period was 786.23 EUR. From the perspective of the health care system, the cost-effectiveness benefit from palonosetron use was 244.09 EUR. From the hospitals' perspective, the costs of palonosetron and ondansetron use per successfully treated patient during the 5-day (treatment) period were 531.44 EUR and 594.38 EUR, respectively. The cost-effectiveness benefit conferred by palonosetron versus ondansetron was 62.94 EUR. From the perspective of statutory health insurance funds, the cost per successfully treated patient was 10.72 EUR for palonosetron versus 191.85 EUR for ondansetron. The cost-effectiveness benefit from palonosetron use was 181.14 EUR.

Conclusions: Antiemetic supportive care of cancer patients using palonosetron was more cost-effective than treatment with ondansetron from each stakeholder's perspective. Background: Capecitabine, an oral fluoropyrimidine recently approved for the treatment of metastatic colon and breast cancer, is currently under investigation in patients with gastric cancer. The following dermatologic reactions associated with the use of capecitabine have been previously reported: palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia, photoeruption, "dermatitis", leopardlike vitiligo, "erythematous rash", onycholysis, pyogenic granulomas, radiation recall, and xerosis.

Methods: A 77-year old woman presented at the Department of Dermatology with a three-week history of erythematosquamous plaques. The patient had been treated with capecitabine for advanced gastric cancer. Seven days after initiation of capecitabine monotherapy, erythematosquamous skin lesions on the face, neck, anterior parts of the upper trunk, the lower arms, the dorsum of the hands and dorsal surfaces of her fingers developed. The patient also noticed increased photosensitivity. Myalgias, arthralgias, or fever were not noted. Previous medical history was otherwise unremarkable.

Results: Laboratory results (anti-Ro antibodies) and histology were consistent with the diagnosis of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE). Treatment with topical steroids and sun protective measures were initiated and after discontinuation of capecitabine treatment, cutaneous lesions completely resolved within 6 weeks and no further SCLE flares were observed.

Conclusions: Lupus erythematosus and lupus-like drug eruptions have been observed after 5-fluorouracil treatment, but so far have not been described in patients treated with capecitabine. As capecitabine is being used increasingly in the treatment of breast and gastrointestinal cancers, clinicians should be aware of this important novel cutaneous adverse reaction.

Development of pemphigus vulgaris after fludarabine treatment despite simultaneous administration of rituximab and cyclophosphamide A. Weimar 1 , R. Feldmann 2 , K. Geissler 1,3 1 5 th Medical Department-Oncology, 2 Department of Dermatology, Hospital Hietzing, Vienna, Austria; 3 Ludwig Boltzmann Institute of Clinical Oncology, Vienna, Austria Background: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a hematological malignancy which may be associated with autoimmune disease such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and idiopathic thrombocytopenia (ITP). Fludarabine is a cytotoxic agent which is increasingly used in the treatment of CLL alone or in combination with other drugs. Increased incidence of AHIA and ITP during fludarabine therapy has been observed. 3 cases of paraneoplastic pemphigus in adult men with CLL have also been reported after fludarabine treatment (C. Gooptu et al, Br J Dermatol 2001) . Rituximab and cyclophosphamide on the other hand have been shown to be effective in some autoimmune diseases. In particular treatment of rituximab and Ig has been shown to be effective in patients with refractory pemphigus vulgaris (R. Ahmed et al, NEJM 2006) .

cite_spans.text: (C. Gooptu et al, Br J Dermatol 2001)

body_text.text: Methods: We report a patient with CLL, who developed severe pemphigus vulgaris after treatment with a immunochemotherapy consisting of rituximab (R), fludarabine (F) and cyclophosphamide (C).

Results: In July 2006 a 60 years old male patient was diagnosed as CLL by histological investigation of a cervical lymph node. WBC was slightly increased (10300/mcl) with 51% lymphocytes and the demonstration of a CD5 coexpressing CD19 positive B-cell clone. Because of B-symptoms, a rapidly progressing lymphadenopathy and the presence of an adverse cytogenetic aberration (11q deletion by FISH) the patient was treated in November with the first R-FC treatment. 2 weeks after chemotherapy the patient presented with bilateral conjunctivitis, blistering exanthema and stomatitis. During the next days exanthema and stomatitis became worse and the patient had to be admitted to the hospital in order to supply parenteral fluid and nutrition. Because of expanding blistering eruption with mucosal involvement pemphigus vulgaris was suspected. A skin biopsy was performed and serum was tested for antibodies against desmoglein. Diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris was confirmed by the demonstration of epidermal acantholysis and keratinocyte necrosis, by immunofluorescence revealing typical binding of both IgG and C3 in a focal, intercellular epidermal pattern and linear granular pattern at the basement membrane, by immunoprecipitation and immunoblotting demonstrating several characteristic target antigens of molecular weights 250kD, 210 kD, 190 kD and 130 kD and the detection of antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 by a sensitive enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Shortly after administering high dose corticosteroids exanthema and mucosal changes significantly improved. At the moment the patient is receiving corticosteroid maintenance therapy.

Conclusions: Since rituximab and cyclophosphamide have been shown to be effective in the treatment of pemphigus vulgaris and an association between fludarabine and pemphigus vulgaris has been observed it is likely that fludarabine may be the causative agent in the development of pemphigus vulgaris in this patient. It is of particular interest that the administration of rituximab and cyclophosphamide given simultaneously with fludarabine was apparently not effective in protecting the patient from this rare but serious complication.

FIGREF12.text: Anticancer drugs must be administered within a defined time and in a defined volume according to the chemical/physical stability and to the efficacy published by clinical studies. When the infusion is finished the residual volume in the infusion line averages 20 ml. The remaining volume in the line of a mini-bag of 100 ml amounts 20% of the substance, in 250 ml 8%, in 500 ml 4% and in 1000 ml 2% of active agent. This poses on the one hand the question of efficacy of the applied chemotherapy and on the other hand economic questions. The aim of this study was the economical analysis of the anticancer drug loss caused by the residual volume in the infusion lines on the oncology ward at the Hospital Oberwart in the year 2006. Methods: The total costs of the i. v. anticancer drugs in the year 2006 amounted to 649,880 €. The costs of the drug loss due to the residual volume in the infusion line added up to 61,551 €.The costs were made up of the loss resulting from the infusion chemotherapies in 100 ml mini-bags (28,750 €), as well as of the loss by using 250 ml bags (29,592 €), 500 ml bags (3161 €) and 1000 ml bags (48 €).

Fridrik 1 1 Innere Medizin 3, Zentrum für Hämatologie und Medizinische Onkologie, 2 Zentrallbor, Allgemeines Krankenhaus Linz, Linz, ÖsterreichGrundlagen: DPD ist das Schlüsselenzym im Abbau von Pyrimidinen (Uracil, Cytosin, Thymin) und deren Analoga wie 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU). Mutationen in der DPD führen zu einer verminderten Enzymaktivität und somit zu einem verlangsamten Abbau von Pyrimidinen. Dies kann bei Patienten, die mit 5-FU oder 5-FU Prodrugs behandelt werden, zu schweren toxischen, im Einzelfall lebensbedrohlichen Nebenwirkungen führen.Methodik: Von Jänner 2004 bis Dezember 2005 untersuchten wir 205 konsekutive Patienten mit verschiedenen Malignomen auf die DPYD-Mutation der IVS14+1G A. Es wurden alle Patienten gescreent, bei denen eine Chemotherapie mit 5-FU oder 5-FU-Prodrug geplant war. Von allen Patienten wurde vorher wurde ein schriftliches Einverständnis eingeholt. Die Untersuchung erfolgte mit einer real-time-PCR mit der LightCycler™-Technologie. Wir berichten über die Wertigkeit dieser Screeninguntersuchung, in Bezug zu den aufgetretenen Diarrhoen, bei Patienten bei denen die Mutation nicht nachgewiesen wurde. Ergebnisse: Eine heterozygote DPYD-Mutation wurde bei 3 Patienten nachgewiesen, diese wurden nicht mit Fluoropyrimidine behandelt. Von den 202 Patienten ohne Mutation erhielten 139 eine pyrimidinhaltige Chemotherapie, 36 nur 5-FU oder Capecitabine, 103 in Kombination mit anderen Chemotherapeutika. Einundachzig Patienten (58 %) erlitten keinen Durchfall, bei 29 (40 %) kam es zum Auftreten leichterer Durchfälle (WHO-Grad I u. II), schwere Diarrhoen (GIII u. IV) traten bei insgesamt 18 Pat. (13 %) auf. Es gab keine Todesfälle, welche auf Durchfallerkrankungen zurückzuführen wären. Schlussfolgerungen: Bei 139 Patienten ohne DPYD-Mutation trat kein Todesfall auf Grund von Durchfall auf. Schwere Durchfälle können aber auch bei Patienten ohne Exon14-Mutation nicht ausgeschlossen werden.
